ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
Basic and advanced knowledge in solid-state physics.
Some experimental skills and physical insights.
I developed a basic familiarity with basic concepts in solid state physics.
more is different, less is more

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
-slow down the pace of classes
-show how to solve some exercises
-start more from the basics, not everybody has taken a solid state class/quantum mechanics class before

Strengths
- The lectures are engaging and clear
- The instructor solicited student feedback during the course and made helpful adjustments
- Aside from a few problems, the homework problems were interesting and tractable
- The grading was generous

Weaknesses
- The midterm required a lot of coding

Suggestions
- Include more problems of easy and moderate difficulty to drill basic concepts

strength: interesting topics 
weakness: too broad, and workload is  too heavy

I feel as though the homework could sometimes be too long, although it became more reasonable in the later half of the course. The midterm and final would introduce new content not covered previously, which I feel is poor practice, as these are supposed to be a test of cumulative knowledge from the course up to that point.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend it only if they have taken a solid state class before

No. The topics covered in this class are fascinating, but you might very well learn more if you just spend all the time reading a standard textbook instead. While the instructor made every effort to seek feedback from students, the course never managed to escape from a disaster in poor delivery and pacing. I lost count of the number of times the instructor said a version of I am not going to go through the math or quickly clicked through screenshot formula in his slides (from multiple sources that for too many times had inconsistent notations). As a result, quick qualitative takeaways that were meant to supplant intuition devolved into hand-waving checkboxes typically seen in a poorly written engineering textbook.
Yes. The course was an interesting and challenging first exposure to solid state physics.
fair. it is just too much workload, I do not have enough time on my research
